issues.description: The return type of Pneumatic.raisePressure(int) is inconsistent between the problem statement (UML) and the solution, and also inconsistent within the solution itself. The UML in the problem statement declares raisePressure(...) : void (problem_statement.md lines 16-19). In the solution repository the Pneumatic interface declares boolean raisePressure(int) (solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Pneumatic.java lines 3-7), but both implementing classes in the solution (LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster) implement raisePressure(int) with a void return type (solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/LaunchedDropdownTower.java lines 9-12 and solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/LaunchedRollerCoaster.java lines 9-12). This mismatch (interface declares boolean while implementations use void, and UML specifies void) is a structural error that will confuse students and cause compilation errors in the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the raisePressure(int) signature consistent across all artifacts. Preferred fix to match the UML/problem statement: change the Pneumatic interface declaration to `void raisePressure(int pressureIncrease);` (update solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Pneumatic.java). Ensure all implementing classes keep the void return type. Alternatively, if the interface is intended to return boolean, update the problem statement/UML and update the implementing classes to return boolean and provide appropriate semantics. The key is to align the interface, implementations, and the UML so they all use the same return type.
